title: coronavirus 5g michael gove nonsense
story: After The Sun revealed the claim had gone viral, the senior minister slapped it down in todays press conference.Mr Gove claimed it was vitally important people were knocking down this rubbish, and warned spreading it put lives at risk.He said: The stories that have gone about that they spread the disease-that’s just nonsense, dangerous nonsense as well.His fury was echoed by National Medical Director of NHS England Stephen Powis.He said: [Its] complete and utter rubbish and the worst kind of fake news.The reality is that the mobile phone networks are absolutely critical to all of us particularly at a time we are asking everybody to stay home.I am absolutely disgusted that people would be taking action against the very infrastructure we need to respond to this health emergency.It is absolute and utter rubbish and I cannot condemn it in stronger terms than that.Mr Gove also revealed the NHS had been boosted by new ventilators, with  arriving from China and even more being made in Britain.He said: Weve been buying invasive ventilators from partners abroad, including Germany and Switzerland, and today  new ventilators arrived from China.Mr Gove added there are now more than , ventilators in the NHS and the aim is to produce and secure even more.It comes after conspiracy nuts were reportedly setting phone masts alight and targeting engineers over a bizarre claim G radiation caused the deadly coronavirus spread.The theory originated last month after a video filmed at a US health conference claimed Africa was not as affected by the disease because it is not a G region.It was quickly debunked after the World Health Organisation confirmed there were thousands of Covid- cases in Africa.The government has also confirmed there is no evidence to suggest that G has anything to do with Covid-.Celebs have been slammed for sharing the conspiracy theory, including Jason Gardiner and Callum Best, who posted similar claims that G can impact the immune system.Boxer Amir Khan also released a series of bizarre videos where he blames the coronavirus on the building of “G towers”.In the clips, Khan admits to “watching a lot of videos and stuff” and says that the new tech could “make things bad”.Just days ago Khan offered the NHS the use of his four-storey wedding venue to help treat patients during the pandemic.

title: coronavirus test makers mystified by matt hancocks 100000 promise
story: Industry leaders tasked with producing COVID- tests said they were blindsided by the four week deadline announced by Matt Hancock, and warned the kits wouldn’t be ready until June.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here thesun whocareswinsappealThe chief representative of the UK’s testing industry said Mr Hancock did not mention the deadline in a video conference shortly before the announcement, and manufacturers said they were “mystied” by the blistering timetable.On Thursday, in his first appearance since battling the virus himself, the Health Secretary pledged to rapidly ramp up the UK’s testing capacity.After the government came under fire for failing to conduct more tests, Mr Hancock said England would deliver , a day by the end of the month.However, manufacturers tasked with producing the kits by the government have said the sudden deadline is not deliverable.Dr Joe Fitchett, medical director of Mologic, a company given £ million by the Department of Health to make a test kit, said they would only be available from June at the earliest.He told The : “That’s very fast to produce something from a prototype.”Dr Fitchett also said he doubts other firms could produce tests quicker: “Anyone can produce rubbish prototypes, as seems to have happened in Spain, unfortunately – but it has to work. It’s a real challenge to make sure you have enough of what you need for the country.”The head representative of the UK’s testing industry echoed Dr Fitchett’s warnings, saying they were not told about end of April deadline in a call with Mr Hancock on Wednesday.Doris-Ann Williams, chief executive of the British In Vitro Diagnostics Association, said: “The target is his target that he set without any consultation with the industry.She told The Times: “So while we’ll do everything we can to help meet it because it’s in our interest as part of the UK population, we can’t make any promises.”Ms Williams said she took part in a video conference with Mr Hancock on the day before his announcement, but “there were no numbers discussed at the meeting and there was no commitment from either side to numbers.”The government has already ordered . million antibody kits, which would tell patientsthey have already had the virus and recovered, and is currently examining their effectiveness.Health officials had indicated that the tests could be available in a matter of weeks, with Boris Johnson calling them a “game-changer”.Earlier this week, Spain ed , testing kits made in China after it emerged they only had a  per cent accuracy rate.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.The warning has dealt a blow to hopes that coronavirus restrictions could be removed in May.Professor Neil Ferguson, who has been advising the government on its COVID- response, said that some of the tightest restrictions could be removed next monththere was a rapid increase in testing.He told BBC Radio s Today programme: We want to move to a situation at least by the end of May that were able to substitute some less intensive measures, more based on technology and testing, for the complete lockdown we have now.He continued: There is a great deal of work underway to look at how we can substitute some of the very intense social distancing currently in place with a regime more based on intensive testing, very rapid access to testing, contact tracing of contracts.But in order to substitute that regime for what were doing now, we need to get case numbers down.The latest figures show that , people have been tested for coronavirus in the UK, with , coming back positive., people have died from the virus. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: neighbours snitch coronavirus lockdown
story: That includes the police. Since Boris Johnson declared the lockdown restrictions on our lives, officers have been accused by some of being overzealous enforcing them.They have tried to stop some shops selling Easter eggs because they consider them non-essential.A cop was also filmed threatening to fine a bakery owner for putting chalk on the pavement outside her shop to maintain social-distancing.Meanwhile, the Derbyshire force dyed black the Blue Lagoon swim spot in a disused Buxton quarry to deter groups from gathering there — and sent out drones to spy on walkers in the middle of nowhere.Road blocks have been set up to check motorists and cyclists are on essential journeys.Last weekend officers were also breaking up groups of more than two people on park benches, and football matches in parks.All of which could seem a tad heavy-handed.So you can see why some people are indignant, especially given the absence of clearer official guidance.Perhaps it is this lack of clarity that is partly the issue.Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said in a recent daily press conference that police should use common sense in applying the rules and that the public should follow the guidance not just to the letter but also the spirit.The real issue, though, is some people’s inability to follow the very basic instruction to stay at home unless they really need to go out.If people were not disregarding this advice, police would not have to enforce it.Officers do need to be careful, though.We are willing to social-distance for the greater good but only as long as it is necessary — and will not tolerate it for a minute longer.We are not a police state and the police must be mindful of being too heavy-handed.So while shouting at someone for buying an Easter egg is ridiculous and using a drone to terrorise a lone dog walker does seem extreme, someone has to break up the cretins who are having barbecues or parties in high-density residential areas, right I do despair over the attitude of those mindless idiots who are still having parties and getting drunk together.Then there are the twits going to DIY shops to buy paint, which is hardly essential.People, this is not an extended Bank Holiday. It is a lockdown.It is being done to save your le or the le of someone you love.The bottom line is that officers have to ensure the guidelines are adhered to, but it is how they go about it that is important.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here thesun whocareswinsappealIn the meantime, police chiefs are urging snoopers to use online hotlines to tell tales about neighbours who are breaching the Government’s lockdown.Humberside has created a dedicated online portal where people can submit tip-offsthey spot gatherings of more than two people.West Midlands, Greater Manchester, and Avon and Somerset are urging the public to alert them to breaches by using online forums, rather than phoning  or .To my mind, this raises ethical questions.hould we really become a nation of snitches Should we not all just concentrate on our own families and trust that others will take care of themselves Is the act of reporting the selfish idiots who disregard the Government advice really community spirit Or is it just the ultimate curtain-twitching exercise — which encourages serious pettiness Apparently, the police have had calls from people asking them to come and arrest a neighbour for going on a second run in one day.In an ideal world we would all just abide by the rules and there would be no need to report others.Sadly, though, needs must.If your neighbour is driving to the seaside when you are stuck indoors at home, they are ruining the purpose of this lockdown for everyone, they are selfish and they should be stopped.If people do not abide by the rules, what choice do you have Butyou do just stay home there will be no need to worry about whether your neighbours are phoning the police about you.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.IT seems assome celebrities are in the process of reinventing themselves.I’m currently feeling a bit guilty for underestimating Kim Kardashian, who is a year into four years of training to become a lawyer.She credits motherhood with being the catalyst for her decision.“Becoming a mom has really opened up my heart, and it’s changed me,” she said.I’m so impressed.It seems that there is much more to Kim than meets the eye.What a great reminder that we are all a work in progress and that we can all change our destiny – even when it might not look to the outside world asthat destiny “needs” changing.ANYONE  as gobsmacked as me about the idiocy of boxing world champion Billy Joe Saunders, who released a video advising men how to hit their female partners In the video, Saunders uses a punch bag to explain how to react“your old woman is giving you mouth” and showing how to hit her on the chin.He later apologised, saying on talkSPORT on Monday that it was a “silly mistake”, he “obviously wasn’t thinking” and that he would “never condone domestic violence”.But it’s hard not to surmise that he only apologised because he was caught.All that God-given talent to be a great boxer but, sadly, the man is a cretin.Happily, his boxing licence has been suspended by the British Boxing Board of Control, his promoter Eddie Hearn said publicly that he was “appalled” by the “idiotic” video and Saunders has said he will donate £, to domestic violence charities.So hopefully he won’t be making the same “mistake” again.I FEEL bad that Carol Vorderman – who is  and who, granted, looks a million dollars – has had to point out how sad it is that people focus on how big her bottom is instead of her fruitful career.In a recent interview, the former Countdown whizz – who is a serious brainbox – talked about her humble beginnings as a free school meals kid who went on to read engineering at Cambridge uni.She now aims to help children from a similar background and has just made her Maths Factor online maths courses free to the entire nation during lockdown, which is pretty amazing.I know some celebrities court publicity precisely on the grounds of how big their bottom is – or rather, used to before they started training as a lawyer.But Carol, who has had a really magnicent career, has so many other things going for her.Isn’t it annoying that this even has to be said LOTS of people have been getting through the lockdown at home by streaming HIIT and other workout videos online.But do you remember the days when the only exercise we could do via a screen was Jane Fonda’s VHS workout, which was released In  and sold more than million copies around the world And, clearly, it kept her in great shape.On Friday, at the age of , she decided to recreate the routine in a TikTok video to raise awareness about climate change.Anyone wearing a red leotard and black leggings is brave in my book, whatever their age.Anyone who does so at the age of  – and looks as fabulously fit as Jane Fonda does – earns their place as a role model in my book.Here’s hoping I look even half as fit, well and fabulous at the age of  as she does.But I bet they are glad they will not be on the receiving end of endless criticism for their choices yet again.I LOVED the story about the nail technician who found a way around all of our lockdown beauty woes with “through the letterbox” manicures.Tasleem Yasir, , from Belfast, was devastated when she was forced to close her home salon due to coronavirus.So her husband Raja decided to make her laugh by asking for a letterbox manicure.She did it for a joke while their -year-old son, Mohammed, recorded it.Tasleem was then inundated with requests from around the world askingshe can provide the same treatment.A month ago we would have all laughed at the idea of a letterbox manicure.After a couple of weeks on lockdown it doesn’t sound quite so barmy after all. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: army recruits reading age five year old
story: Hundreds more with literacy skills of a seven to nine-year-old have signed up.The latest available figures, covering -, show , soldiers had the reading ability of nine to -year-olds.Fty had levels expected of a five to seven-year-old.They could join despite Army rules barring recruits below Entry Level Two — the seven to nine-year-old range.The National Literacy Trust says adults below Level Two may not be able to read a label on a medicine bottle.A source said: “This shows how desperate the Army has become.“Recruits need some degree of education to communicate, grasp ideas and understand operational briefings.“A lot of equipment is also quite complex and they will need a decent grasp of English to understand instruction.”In January  there were , regular personnel, down from , in .Up to , leave the services every year amid complaints over pay and conditions.An Army spokesman said: “In certain instances candidates have been permitted to join at Level One on the understanding they attend college to bring them up to the minimum standard before commencing basic training.”Former commander Col Richard Kemp insisted: “Many will be bright but simply not given the chance to shine at school.“The Army will teach them what they need to know.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: think of lucys face if youre tempted to ignore social isolation this weekend
story: Protecting the NHS has to start meaning that our frontline NHS heroes all have the personal protective equipment they need every time they go to work and put their lives on the line to save those of strangers.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealProtecting the NHS needs to start meaning that doctors, nurses and health carers all have quick and easy access to testing that tells themthey have the virus — or not.Protecting the NHS must start meaning that we never again witness chaotic scenes like the ones in the Ikea car park in Wembley, North West London, this week, where NHS workers queued for hours to be tested and then were turned away because they did not have the correct paperwork.In a time of national emergency I am reluctant to criticise a Government facing an un­preceden­ted national health crisis.But this is pathetic.And it is certainly not “Protecting the NHS”.When the little boats were rescuing our Army on the beaches of Dunkirk, were soldiers stopped from getting on board because they lacked the correct paperwork  Turning up at a testing centre with a valid NHS ID card should be all that any exhausted, over­worked NHS worker ever needs.Only a few thousand out of half a million of our frontline NHS heroes have been tested.NHS trusts send tests to Germany because they get the results quicker than they do here — and yet some testing centres, like the one in Chessington, Surrey, stand empty.That scandalous state of affairs is not protecting the NHS in the way it needs and, God knows, deserves.And it is not just the Government that needs to up its game.Public Health England , the agency responsible for organising national coronavirus testing, has not been fit for purpose.PHE has an annual budget of £.billion to “protect and improve the nation’s health and well-being” and  senior executives coining six-figure salaries.But Germany is doing , coronavirus tests EVERY DAY while in the UK the figure is just ,.PHE is doing a lousy job protecting the health of the nation, and the NHS.There are currently , NHS workers off sick or self-isolating, with no ideathey have corona­virus. This is nowhere near good enough.As Boris Johnson croaked from his sick bed, mass testing among the general population is the ONLY way out of this national purgatory.But at the moment we do not even have widespread testing among our NHS workers.Right now we are letting down those selfless doctors, nurses and health carers.On Thursday night at pm, my street in North London resounded to the sound of grateful clapping for our carers.But as our frontline health workers start to die, they need more than a weekly standing ovation.They need us to understand that the lockdown rules apply to us all.Lucy Hutchings, , is a nurse caring for coronavirus patients in Southampton.In a Facebook post, shared , times, she wrote it is “devastating” to see so much suffering when there are still people not following simple rules about staying home, staying safe and protecting the NHS.“I’m scared, everybody I work with is scared,” wrote Lucy, her face etched with exhaustion after another gruelling -hour sht.“The quicker people stay indoors, the quicker it will be over.“I’d like to stay at home but I can’t, so for people to go against the rules is so stupid and irresponsible.“I keep myself away from my mum, dad and brother because I don’t want to pass the virus on. It’s a hard thing to do.”Lucy’s face should haunt us all.Remember it every time some thick-as-mince footballer wraps his expensive motor around a lamppost.Remember Lucy’s face every time you see people who think social isolation rules do not apply to them.Remember Lucy’s faceyou want to understand what a long way we have to go before we truly start supporting the NHS.Yes, it is hard for a people raised in freedom to obey these restrictive rules.But NOBODY has a harder job right now than those NHS workers who are risking their lives in under-equipped, overcrowded hospitals that are being pushed to breaking point and beyond.The health crisis is unprecedented in our letime but the Government cannot keep cocking it up.The NHS does not have the kit it needs, the testing it needs, the support it needs.Health Secretary Matt Hancock promises , coronavirus tests a day by the end of April.If Hancock does not deliver, get shot of him.Because right now, that “Protect the NHS” slogan is looking heartbreakingly empty.All foreign NHS workers who are out there now fighting on the frontline deserve British passports.If these foreign heroes are good enough to risk their lives to save our lives, then they have earned the right to stay in the UK for ever.CLAUDIA Schfer tells Elle magazine that at the height of her supermodel glory days she felt like a rock star. She reveals that she wouldfrom another hard sht on the runway to discover that her bra and knickers had been stolen by obsessive fans.“It was insane,” she says. “Like being a rock star.”Well, not quite, Claudia. And they take advantage now to say, ‘Yes, I’ve been a victim’. There is a lot of hypocrisy.”It’s a bit rich someone from the Bond franchise complaining about hypocrisy.Daniel Craig said in  that he would “rather slash his wrists” than play James Bond again.And what could be more hypocritical than that, Lea AS this newspaper pointed out last week, it is totally bonkers that archaic Sunday trading laws restrict large grocery stores to just six hours of trading on Sundays.Nobody in the country is finding it easy to buy essential shopping for their family right now.Yet supermarkets can’t stay open for longer than six hours on a Sunday, even though the hours of convenience stores are not limited by prehistoric trading laws.The Department for Food says it has no plans to extend Sunday trading hours. story: The -year-old NBA legend along with eight others — including his daughter Gianna — died in January when the helicopter he was aboard crashed in Calabasas, Calornia.The NBA superstar retired in  as the third-leading scorer in league history.But Bryant will be posthumously inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame along with fellow NBA greats Tim Duncan and Kevin Garnett.His we Vanessa spoke of her pride that the LA Lakers star was announced in the Class of .Speaking to ESPN, she said: Its an incredible accomplishment and honor, and were extremely proud of him.Every accomplishment that he had as an athlete was a steppingstone to be here.Obviously we wish that he was here with us to celebrate.Were incredibly proud of him. title: social media bosses crack down crazed coronavirus conspiracies
story: SOCIAL media bosses have been told to crack down on crazed conspiracy theories claiming G radiation sparked coronavirus.Two masts were reportedly torched this week amid the bizarre claims that they were behind the pandemic.The first mast in the Sparkhill area in Birmingham went up in flames on Thursday and the second was in the M area near Liverpool on Friday.And Culture Secretary James Dowden will now issue a warning to all social media sites and messaging s to curb conspiracy theories, fake scientic reports and scams relating to the Covid- outbreak.A spokesman said: “We are calling on tech firms to prevent this nonsense spreading.There is absolutely no evidence of a link between G and coronavirus.”Liverpool mayor Joe Anderson earlier revealed: I’ve reported a tweet to police which said ‘If you don’t halt them [the masts] Joe, we will.During todays press conference, Michael Gove slapped down the bogus claims after The Sun revealed the G rumours had gone viral.Mr Gove claimed it was vitally important people were knocking down this rubbish, and warned spreading it put lives at risk.He said: The stories that have gone about that they spread the disease - thats just nonsense, dangerous nonsense as well.His fury was echoed by National Medical Director of NHS England Stephen Powis.He said: [Its] complete and utter rubbish and the worst kind of fake news.The reality is that the mobile phone networks are absolutely critical to all of us particularly at a time we are asking everybody to stay home.I am absolutely disgusted that people would be taking action against the very infrastructure we need to respond to this health emergency.It is absolute and utter rubbish and I cannot condemn it in stronger terms than that.Mr Gove also revealed the NHS had been boosted by new ventilators, with  arriving from China and even more being made in Britain.He said: Weve been buying invasive ventilators from partners abroad, including Germany and Switzerland, and today  new ventilators arrived from China.Mr Gove added there are now more than , ventilators in the NHS and the aim is to produce and secure even more.It comes after conspiracy nuts were reportedly setting phone masts alight and targeting engineers over a bizarre claim G radiation caused the deadly coronavirus spread.The theory originated last month after a video filmed at a US health conference claimed Africa was not as affected by the disease because it is not a G region.It was quickly debunked after the World Health Organisation confirmed there were thousands of Covid- cases in Africa.The government has also confirmed there is no evidence to suggest that G has anything to do with Covid-.Celebs have been slammed for sharing the conspiracy theory, including Jason Gardiner and Callum Best, who posted similar claims that G can impact the immune system.Boxer Amir Khan also released a series of bizarre videos where he blames the coronavirus on the building of “G towers”.In the clips, Khan admits to “watching a lot of videos and stuff” and says that the new tech could “make things bad”.Just days ago Khan offered the NHS the use of his four-storey wedding venue to help treat patients during the pandemic.

title: coronavirus scotland catherine calderwood chief medic covid 19
story: HERE is Scotland’s Chief Medical Officer defying her own government’s advice during the virus lockdown — after travelling to her second home.Dr Catherine Calderwood, , tweeted a snap of her family clapping the NHS outside her Edinburgh pad on Thursday.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updates on Covid-But on Saturday she was pictured  miles away walking with her husband and children near their coastal retreat in posh Earlsferry, Fe.One local blasted: “It’s double standards.”It comes days after SNP bosses called for powers to stop second home owners travelling to rural areas.Dr Catherine Calderwood, , was snapped strolling across a golf course with her husband and kids after flouting lockdown advice by heading to her coastal property this weekend.The top medic, who has become one of the key figures in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic, was spotted out and about in Earlsferry, Fe — an hour and ten minute drive from her home in Edinburgh.Tonight a source accused the doctor — who took the Hippocratic Oath to protect patients — of “dangerous double standards”.They added: “Either we are in lockdown or not  I’m pretty sure government advice is to stay at home and not to travel to second holiday homes.“But Catherine Calderwood isn’t following the advice. She and her family are potentially bringing the virus to the area.”Wearing a turquoise jacket, Dr Calderwood looked like she didn’t have a care in the world as she walked with her family and dogs near her bolthole on Saturday.But locals in the quiet coastal town hit out over the seemingly unnecessary trip, which came after a working week in Edinburgh where she spoke at daily pandemic press briefings alongside First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.Residents accused her of failing to heed her own government’s advice that people with second properties should stay at home to protect rural communities during the outbreak.The source said Dr Calderwood was one of several other high-flyers from Edinburgh who had second properties in the area and were putting locals at risk.One onlooker told The Scottish Sun on Sunday: “They were going for a walk with the dogs. It’s weird.“I thought she lived in Edinburgh and that we were supposed to stay home — but this place is miles away.”On Thursday, Dr Calderwood shared a photo of her family outside her capital home taking part in the national Clap for Carers event.The image was posted as millions ventured on to their doorsteps to applaud our NHS heroes and care workers.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThe snap was taken in the driveway of her upmarket West End home — said to be worth around £.million.Under the hashtag ‘clap for NHS’, the health bigwig told her , followers: “My family clapping my NHS and care colleagues — and me! Thank you all.”The following day the Cambridge and Glasgow Universities graduate attended an official Scottish Government press call where she delivered crucial public health advice alongside Ms Sturgeon.But today the mum of three angered locals after she was seen walking her dogs with her husband and children across the golf course and heading towards the beach in picturesque Earlsferry, where she has a cosy bungalow.Dr Calderwood has given regular press conferences on the Covid- pandemic at St Andrew’s House in Edinburgh where she has repeatedly urged the public to stay within their homes.The government building is just . miles from her Edinburgh pad. But her second home in Earlsferry is  miles away from the capital.This weekend’s trip comes just days after Nats chiefs called for emergency powers to stop second-home owners self-isolating in rural areas, including the Highlands.MP Ian Blackford said legislation should be used to protect areas with less health infrastructure from visitors trying to flee the coronavirus.He spoke out after a number of communities reacted angrily as tourists blocked lay-bys and swamped camping areas.Mr Blackford, the SNP’s leader at Westminster, said: “With Easter almost upon us it is worth reminding everyone of the emergency powers that restrict non-essential travel.“That means no tourists should be coming to the Highlands and Islands.“If anyone owns a second or holiday home they should not be using the Highlands to self-isolate and powers exist and must be used to stop this.”Similar warnings have also been issued in England and Wales.UK Health Secretary Matt Hancock said he did not consider people going to their holiday homes as an essential trip during the crisis.His plea followed concerns that rural health services could be overwhelmed by those leaving cities who then end up suffering from Covid-.Mr Hancock said: “We’ve said that people should not take unnecessary journeys, no unnecessary travel and I don’t regard going to your holiday home as a necessary journey.”Today it was revealed that a further  people have died from coronavirus in Scotland, bringing the total number of deaths to .The UK-wide total increased by  to ,.The latest deaths including a child aged just five — the youngest UK victim so far.The Scottish Government said , people had now tested positive for the virus, an increase of  from Friday.In total, , patients have been tested across the country.We told how people are now only permitted to leave their homesthey have “reasonable excuse”.This includes work that cannot be carried out at home, shopping for food and medical supplies and an hour of daily exercise.In the six days since new legislation was introduced, police officers have been forced to issue  fixed penalty notices to people who have chosen to ignore the measures.Belfast-born Dr Calderwood has pleaded with Scots to stay at home to protect the NHS and “help save lives” — including on TV and radio ads and at daily press briefings on the pandemic with Ms Sturgeon.The health chief is a trained consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist.She is also a member of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and is an honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh.When asked to explain the official view on travelling to a second home tonight, a Scottish Government spokesman said: “We strongly advise against any travel to second homes.“It runs the risk of adding pressure to services in more remote and quieter areas, from food supply to health care.”The Scottish Sun on Sunday then asked why the Chief Medical Officer was ignoring official advice.An SNP Government spokesman replied: “Since this start of this epidemic, the CMO has been working seven days a week preparing Scotland’s response.“She took the opportunity this weekend to check on a family home in Fe as she knows she will not be back again until the crisis is over.“She stayed overnight before ing to Edinburgh. In line with guidance she stayed within her own household group and observed social distancing with anyone she was in passing in the village.oliver.norton@the-sun

title: swedens top coronavirus doc britains lockdown too far
story: THE scientist leading Sweden’s battle against the coronavirus has claimed that Britains lockdown goes too far.Epidemiologist Anders Tegnell believes the UK shouldnt have abandoned its original strategy as bars, restaurants and schools in his country remain open.Sweden has currently recorded  deaths of the coronavirus, with just over , infections.This puts it far below Britain which is in lockdown, though it is around two weeks behind on the curve of the virus.Le in the country remains normal with cafes and restaurants packed, although PM Stefan Lovren has limited gatherings to  and urged Swedes to behave like adults.But doctors have warned that the country could be heading for a catastrophe as the virus continues to spread in public spaces.The countrys leading coronavirus doc Anders Tegnell, who studied at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, told the Mail on Sunday he is sceptical about the benefits of a lockdown.He said: I am very sceptical of lockdowns altogether butyou ever do them, you should do them at an early stage.At certain times I suppose they can be useful,you are unprepared and need more intensive care facilities, for example, but you are really just pushing the problem ahead of you.Mr Tegnell added that he believes his method of fighting the virus, while dferent to every other country, is producing results.He added: So far, what we are doing is working. In a sense we are beating it, and I am confident we are doing the best we can in the circumstances.We can’t kill all our services. And unemployed people are a great threat to public health. title: matt hancock blasts sunbathers parks
story: After photographs of people ignoring the rules and spending their weekends lying around sunning themselves, the Heath Secretary came out to remind them they were risking lives.The number of deaths rose by  yesterday - the highest amount since the crisis began.He told Sky News Sophy Ridge on Sunday this morning: To the very small minority who are continuing to flout the guidance -you are putting others lives at risk and you are putting yourself in harms way.He said it was quite unbelievable that a small minority were openly ignoring the advice to only go outside for just four reasons - exercise, work, fetching medicine or food, or taking care of the vulnerable.We are crystal clear in the guidance what people should or shouldnt do, he stressed.This is not a request, its a requirement.People need to follow it.The ignorant sunbathers ignored warnings from Britains chief nurse on Friday afternoon, who begged them to listen.Ruth May urged them to do it for the two nurses, both mothers, who lost their lives in the Covid- fight this week.Aimee O’Rourke, , and Areema Nasreen, , sadly passed away after treating coronavirus patients on the frontline.Two other healthcare assistants have also died in the last  hours - with nine medics now killed by the virus.Boris Johnson also stressed to the public they must avoid the temptation of enjoying the good weather this weekend.He said today: Thank you to everyone who is saving lives by staying at home this weekend.I know its tough, butwe all work together and follow the guidance, we will beat coronavirus.Britain is set for temperatures of  degrees today, and there are fears Brits will continue to flout the rules to get out and enjoy the good weather.Yesterday Brockwell Park in London said it would close after , people ignored the rules.Cassiobury Park in Watford is also closed after hundreds chose to head for a picnic in the sun rather than obey government guidelines, as well as Lundersten Bay in Scotland.Police in the UK capital were also forced to break up an th birthday attended by  guests who flouted the social distancing guidelines set out by the government amid the coronavirus outbreak.Surrey Road Police also shared a shocking video of Richmond Bridge in West London packed with people out walking along the Thames.In a tweet, they urged Brits to PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE stay at home.Police were also out in force in Brighton in case Brits descend on the seaside town to enjoy the mini heatwave.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal Mr Hancock also said that eight per cent of NHS staff are off sick with coronavirus - title: angela rayner labour deputy leader who
story: The -year-old former Shadow Secretary of State for Education will serve alongside new Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer.Angela Rayner was born in Stockport, Greater Manchester on March  .She is the youngest person to be the shadow education secretary, at the age of .Mrs Rayner went to Avondale School, but left aged  when she became pregnant, without any qualications.She later studied part time at Stockport College, and qualied as a social care worker.She then joined Unison because of the conditions she saw during the decade she worked for in that profession.Mrs Rayner was once under fire for bullying a shopkeeper and misusing Commons notepaper, when she failed to get a special edition of Star Wars high heels.Mrs Rayner joined the Labour Party in , an MP for Ashton-under-Lyne.Jeremy Corbyn appointed her to the position of the shadow secretary for education in .She was then elected deputy leader this morning alongside new Labour leader Keir Starmer.Rayner posted her acceptance speech on Twitter earlier today, where she thanked voters for their support.She is currently recovering from the coronavirus at home after testing positive.Mrs Rayner married her husband Mark, a Union official in .The pair now have three children.She had her firstborn Ryan at the age of  and once said that she felt she was worthless.Mrs Rayner responded to Boris Johnsons ill-comments of single mothers, saying: I think it’s absolutely disgusting. I remember people like that making those comments about me.I might be the shadow education secretary, but inside I’m that -year-old that didn’t think I was worth anything. And people like him make women who are already vulnerable feel that they’re the problem. They’re not the problem.Mrs Rayner became a grandma at the age of , and called herself Grangela.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: who keir starmer new labour leader
story: Heres everything we know about the former shadow Brexit secretary.Keir Starmer is a barrister and politician from London.He was a human rights lawyer before becoming an MP, and co-founded Doughty Street Chambers in .The barrister has worked to eradicate the death penalty in the Caribbean, and Africa, and most recently in Taiwan.He worked as human rights adviser to the Policing Board in Northern Ireland, monitoring compliance of the Police Service of Northern Irelandwith the Human Rights Act.In  he was appointed Director of Public Prosecutionsand Head of the Crown Prosecution Service for England and Wales.In  he was awarded a knighthood for services to law and criminal justice, although he prefers not to be referred to as sir.He told the Ham  High newspaper that he has never liked titles.He said: When I was DPP, everyone called me director and I said, Please dont call me director, call me Keir Starmer. Its a very similar battle now.Two years after his knighthood, he replaced Emily Thornberry as shadow Brexit secretary and supported a second referendum on the vote at the  general election.He announced his candidacy for Labours leadership election on January th.After winning a majority of .%, Keir Starmer was elected as Labour leader this morning after last nights leadership election.He raked in , votes, amassing more than Mr Corbyn did when he was first elected as leader.Running alongside him, candidate Rebecca Long Bailey won , votes while Wigan MP Lisa Nandy also fell short but is set for a job in the shadow cabinet.Ladbrokes previously placed Sir Keir favourite for the post, offering odds of   in February.In September, a recording, published by HuffPost UK, exposed the isions between Mr Corbyn and frontbenchers, who have tried to oust him.Starmer was caught on tape saying “a lot of people” think the party would do better without Jeremy Corbyn as leader.The pair repeatedly clashed over Brexit policy with Sir Keir wanting the party to push harder for a second referendum.Starmer has been Member of Parliamentfor Holborn and St Pancras.He was elected to the seat in  with a majority of ,.He boosted this majority in  to ,, before securing his seat again in  with over  per cent of the vote.In an interview with , Mr Starmer said: The case for a bold and radical Labour government is as strong now as it was last Thursday [the  General Election].He added that Labours values include opposing “the moral injustice of poverty, inequality, homelessness” while advocating for internationalism and human rights.Heres a breakdown of some of his views:The politician is married to solicitor, Victoria Starmer.The couple married in .The pair have two children together, a son and a daughter.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Hundreds of ventilators from China have arrived in the UK today to help the country fight the coronavirus outbreak, Michael Gove said during a news conference.The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster said hundreds of new ventilators are being manufactured every day in the UK and more are being bought from abroad - including  which arrived from China today. Mr Gove said the NHS now has more than , ventilators and the government aims to increase capacity. He said a team from University College London working with Mercedes Benz has produced a new non-invasive respirator that has been clinically approved. Mr Gove said the device is vital in reducing the number of patients who eventually need to be intubated. He said: They produced  yesterday, they will produce the same number today and tomorrow, rising to , a day next week. We are also increasing the capacity of the NHS to deploy invasive ventilation, we have been buying invasive ventilators from partners abroad including Germany and Switzerland. And today  new ventilators arrived from China. Mr Gove said the first devices ordered from Oxford-based medical devices company Penlon will begin arriving in hospitals next week, delivered by the Ministry of Defence.  He said the first devices from Smiths Group had been received at MoD Donnington - a military logistics hub in Shropshire. Mr Gove said: The initial dispatch is the result of scaled up manufacturing of an existing mechanical ventilator design and I am grateful for the efforts of an industry consortium including GKN Aerospace and Rolls Royce. These ventilators will be distributed to hospitals next week.  The Cabinet Office minister said ventilators are essential to give patients the care they need - adding that the government is doing all it can to ease the crisis. He said: The more ventilators - invasive and non-invasive - available to the NHS, the more patients get the care they need, when they need it. But the process of design, assembly, testing and manufacture does take time and we need to make sure that these devices are safe and their manufacture scaleable. Mr Gove also said that the new Nightingale Hospital at Londonaposs ExCel centre can treat  patients on ventilators. He added more field hospitals are being built in Birmingham, Bristol, Cardf, Belfast, Glasgow, Harrogate and Manchester.Mr Gove urged people to stay inside over the weekend, resisting the temptation of going out because of the sunny weather. Speaking about the importance of social distancing, he said: More than ever, we must stick with it. I know that le under lockdown can be challenging, and some will be tempted on this sunny weekend to venture out and about. If we relax our adherence to the rules, we increase the risk for others.

story: NewsJacob Rees Moggs investment firm set to make fortune from the coronavirus crisisEXCLUSIVE: Somerset Capital Management, which the MP co-founded, says market volatility offers a “once or twice in a generation” opportunity to make “super normal s”ShareCommentsByAlan Selby:,  APR NewsTory Jacob Rees-Mogg is reportedly already worth more than £million " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTory toff Jacob Rees-Mogg’s firm stands to make a fortune out of the turmoil caused by the coronavirus crisis. The MP owns at least  per cent of a company investing in businesses hit by falling share values. Somerset Capital Management says investors have a “once in a generation” chance of “super normal s”. Mr Rees-Mogg stood down as a director of SCM to become Leader of the House of Commons. SCM said it was focusing on clients’ long-term security. It came as the UK death toll rose by a record  – including a boy aged five. As millions face financial misery, SCM managers are buying into businesses where valuations have tumbled – but should bounce back. Potential gains of  per cent are touted. Investments so far include private hospitals in Brazil, pharmacies in South Africa and a firm behind a scanning device which checkspeople are wearing masks in China. The revelation was greeted with dismay by new Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer, who said: “Nobody should be seeking to take advantage of this crisis.We should all be asking ourselves what we can do for our country and each other.” Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell added: “This is about as sick as it comes. Profit seeking from suffering is nearly as low as you can get. When we come through this we need a tax on profiteers.” SCM’s strategy comes amid a crisis that has killed , globally, while a further ,, are infected. The UK death toll yesterday rose  to ,. Some , have tested positive. While the economic impact has seen almost a million Brits sign up for Universal Credit, finance houses have been quick to move. Mr Rees-Mogg, , stood down as a director of SCM so he could become Leader of the Commons last July. But he owns at least  per cent, meaning he was entitled to a reported £million share of last year’s £.million profits.  Father-of-six Mr Rees-Mogg, who lives in a mansion in Somerset, is reportedly worth more than £million. That could risea plan by SCM’s Emerging Markets Discovery Fund pays off.Fund boss Mark Asquith said in promotional material that investors could capitalise on smaller companies in particular, with prices down up to  per cent. He wrote: “History has shown us that super normal s can be made during this type of environment.Market dislocations of this magnitude happen rarely, perhaps once or twice in a generation, and have historically provided excellent entry points for investors.”  Mr Asquith cited  per cent profits made after the  crisis and suggested “we could see similar moves”. SCM, which has a £.billion portfolio of client funds, is so keen to attract investors it has waived a .% management fee. Giving examples where they hope to profit, Mr Asquith’s co-manager Christopher White identied Hapvida, a Brazilian medical insurance company which also runs hospitals. It has a deal to care for patients in the public health system. Stock has also been bought in Clicks, South Africa’s leading pharmacy.SCM is also invested in Advantech – behind technology rolled out in China to monitor mask wearing and temperatures of people in public places. SCM was co-founded by Mr Rees-Mogg in . His office declined to comment last night.  The firm is managed in part via the tax havens of the Cayman Islands and Singapore. In November the Sunday Mirror revealed SCM traded shares in a firm fined for its role in the  Deepwater Horizon oil spill disaster. It also had holdings of £million in a Russian bank suspected of helping the annexation of Crimea and pro-Putin terrorists in the Ukraine.

A minority of people have not followed the guidance - regrettably we have to act. Sussex Police tweeted on Saturday evening: Thank you to everyone that stayed away from beauty spots and beaches today. We know it isnapost easy. We are disappointed that two people will be summonsed to attend court after breaching the Coronavirus Act  by having a BBQ on #Hove beach. In the North East, surfers were pictured on the beach at Tynemouth. Mr Gove urged people to consider the current pressure on the NHS, and to ask themselves: How am I helping in this shared national effort  He added: I know that lockdown is challenging, I know itaposs very dficult, particularly for families with children. But people must at every stage respect these guidelines because that is the only way of making sure we restrict the spread of the disease.  Pleas to adhere to the lockdown are being transmitted nationwide, and Bournemouth pier has been adorned with the message Stay home with just a few people seen making their way along the mostly deserted sands on Saturday. There were similarly sparse scenes in Canon Hill Park in Birmingham, where a few people were pictured out running.  Earlier on Saturday, second homeowners were told to keep away from their holiday properties as police forces warned they would issue fines to anyone making non-essential journeys this weekend. Gloucestershire Police said officers will stop people who look like they may be heading away for a few days. The force said: There has been particular concern among some communities that people who own second homes in the area will be visiting over the Easter holiday, and they may put extra pressure on the local NHS.

title: voice mirror fatcats tories dont
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Fatcats and Tories don’t know value of our real heroesThe willingness of NHS staff to cobble kit together from whatever they can find is inspiring, because it shows what can be achieved in adversity - but it is also shaming, because as a rich, industrialised nation we should have done more for themShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR NewsopinionDr Alfa Saadu did not need to work, but he did not hesitate to join , retired NHS workers on the coronavirus frontline " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDr Alfa Saadu did not need to work. But he did not hesitate to join , retired NHS workers on the coronavirus frontline. After  years saving lives, Dr Saadu, , lost his own last week at London’s Whittington Hospital after contracting Covid-. The surgeon’s son described his dad as a “living legend”. And that is true of all those putting their lives on the line to tend to the sick and dying. All are living legends. They battle an invisible invader with too little testing of their own health and not enough personal protection equipment to keep them safe. Their willingness to cobble together kit from whatever they can find is inspiring, shaming and humbling in equal measure. Inspiring, because it shows what can be achieved in adversity. Shaming, because, as a rich nation, we should have done more for them. Humbling, because they carry on regardless. Dr Saadu was not the first medic to die of this nasty, creeping disease. And tragically he will not be the last. Behind doctors, nurses and paramedics, a whole army of NHS workers are also toiling round the clock. The hospital porters, cleaners and caterers, the drivers, the volunteers, the maintenance and admin staff. Alongside them are the key workers who keep our nation ticking over in these perilous times – the shelf-stackers and shop assistants, the posties, truckers, delivery drivers, refuse collectors and utility workers. And the , selfless helpers who stepped forward to ensure the old and vulnerable are not forgotten. Thursday, pm, is proving itself a moving moment as a grateful nation unites to honour them. We reach out to each other in the only way social distancing allows – by putting our hands together. The response of our country to this calamity has been truly astounding. Even those twiddling their thumbs at home are doing their bit by staying there.  Astounding, too, is the response from Somerset Capital Management, the investment firm founded by House of Commons lounge lizard Jacob Rees-Mogg. While Britain has all eyes on a multiplying virus, these virulent fatcats can see no further than multiplying pound signs. While millions face being struck down by Covid-, SCM delights in a “once in a generation opportunity” to make millions by cashing in on the crisis. If Mr Rees-Mogg had an iota of honour, he would disown these grubby profiteers. A politician of real integrity would now sever his links with the company altogether. He may be worth millions, but in the coronavirus stakes his value falls far short of a doctor or nurse. It is their skill and dedication we rely on now to save our lives. It is their caring and compassion which will comfort those reaching the end of theirs.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn her own words, Barbara Currie, now , tells Notebook magazine how she turned to yoga aged , and has never looked back... I am living proof that you’re never too old to do anything. Nor is it ever too late to change your le. I was  years old when I discovered yoga. Before that I’d been living a glamorous le as cabin crew for British Airways. Travel was rare and expensive back in those days, you had to be very wealthy to fly on planes, so it was quite amazing. I loved it. But a rubbish rule back then was that, when you got married, you were no longer eligible for the job. I met my husband three years in and we went on to have two children and moved to Scotland as a family. Well, what a lestyle change! I didn’t know anybody and felt quite lonely with two small kids, so I decided to explore what was going on in the local area. There were two things – curling and yoga. Curling to me looked way too much like sweeping up, so I booked onto yoga, having no idea what it was. When the teacher turned up I was in awe. She was in her early s and just looked fantastic. She was so flexible and could do everything with ease and total vitality. I thought, ‘Whatever she’s doing, it works.’ I was exhausted and stressed with the children and the move when I walked in, but when I left I felt so much lighter. I couldn’t stop thinking about how effortless my teacher made it look. I was hooked. My teacher went on to inspire me, but she was very strict. Posture had to be perfect, she discussed anatomy and physiology with us, and we were expected to really know our stuff. She was an incredible teacher. After a year I decided I wanted to be a yoga teacher. In  I started my three-year course, getting stronger with each session. Now, it wasn’t easy.  I genuinely thought I was quite flexible after all these lovely skiing and surfing lessons I’d been lucky enough to have during my time with BA, but I was stf as a board when I started my training course. Now I know that’s been an advantage in my career –I can do it, anyone can. My first class was a complete accident and I wasn’t prepared. My teacher called in sick and asked me to step in. I managed to do it, but realised how dficult it was to explain things. However, after a while, when I saw some people struggling and I managed to help, I completely forgot about myself. Yoga is absolutely the best thing for your mental health, in my opinion. With all the dismal things going on around us, it teaches us to train our minds and focus on things we are grateful for and practise blue-sky thinking – things that we really want to happen. But it’s also a lot better in terms of physical exercise than people may realise. It tones, it helps joints, it strengthens your bones, helps your breathing, helps your heart and rids you of any tension. Whatever your ailment, I have a pose for it! Oryou want to come to a class and just lie on the mat, that’s fine too. It’s important to give our bodies what they need. Nowadays, yoga is very trendy, but back when I started it was known by so few. My classes became so popular that a journalist from The Daily Mirror called me up and invited me in for an interview on this new ‘craze’ back in .  From that the Mirror asked me to do a fitness video. It sold for £. and sales went through the roof! I couldn’t believe it when I was invited on morning telly to teach live yoga. My whole le changed. I’d be getting my shopping and people would say such nice things. They’d ask, ‘How did you do that one ’ and I’d give a live demonstration in the fruit and veg aisle. People are very kind, aren’t they  So I’m always happy to help. After that I went on to make  videos, which have sold millions worldwide. The most popular was The Age Free Body . I do believe that, as long as you go carefully, youthfulness is an attitude. There is no reason why those in their s and s can’t practise yoga. All you’re doing is gently working on your body and training it to a state of perfect health. It’s also judgement-free exercise, because no matter what level you do, it keeps you healthy, so it doesn’t matter what anybody  thinks. As for me, I practise yoga every day for about an hour by myself, and I am very conscious of my diet. I’ve always been fascinated by nutrition. As a war baby, all we thought about was food. Then everything was rationed until I was about aged seven, so food wasn’t consumed greedily, we just hoped we had enough to eat.  I once saw a doctor who explained that so many people on medication could be helped through pure, natural food and I tried it for a week. I’ve never changed my diet in  years. I eat fresh fruit, fresh vegetables, a little cheese, chicken, fish, milk, but skip all junk. No sweets, cakes, puddings, and instead I just eat fresh beautul food. The only sugar I have now is figs. They are rather lovely and I love a couple after dinner. I even swerve birthday cake. I know it sounds awful to say I haven’t had a slice of cake for  years, but it’s true. It’s not depriving myself, I just love my diet and how it makes me feel. I never drink alcohol. I used to have the odd glass of fizz as cabin crew and hated how it made me feel. But I feel great, quite honestly, and touch wood I’ve never been poorly. That’s not to say that diet goes hand in hand with yoga. People shouldn’t feel miserable about their bodies. You can be bigger and flexible. Often those new to exercise feel scared about taking the first step, but I make them realise that no one is perfect.  It’s lovely seeing clients encouraged when the person next to them can now do a pose they could never do. They’re always happy for each other. I love to help people start feeling proud of themselves again. I live in London with my husband and still teach  times a week. My oldest lady is  and she’s been with me for  years. What a lovely le I’ve been able to have all through my hobby. My family have adapted well to my fame. They see ft cut-outs of me in shops next to my DVDs and say, ‘Hello Mum’. If you’ve never tried yoga, you’ll finish your first class feeling like you’re walking on air. It’s never too late to change your le and you never have to slow down.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK is getting ready to enter its third week in lockdown, with people instructed to stay at home to curb the spread of coronavirus. Despite high visitor numbers to parks and beaches suggesting fatigue may be setting in, Brits have been warned to be ready to hunker down for the long haul, as cases of the deadly bug could keep rising for another two to three weeks. Despite hopes that drastic social distancing measures will soon flatten the curve of the Covid- pandemic, Professor Paul Cosford, Public Health Englandaposs Medical Director, has warned that lockdown measures are nowhere near ending. Other experts, however, such as government adviser Professor Graham Medley of Imperial College London have argued that prolonged periods of lockdown could cause more harm than coronavirus itself, leading to soaring unemployment, food poverty, domestic violence and mental illness. So how long is it likely to last and who will decide when and how to end the restrictions  Follow the latest coronavirus updates here  When will the UK end lockdown  It is not yet clear when the UK will be able to lt its strict social distancing and lockdown measures. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is due to review the measures for the first time next week, however when asked about an exit strategy at the daily press conference on Saturday, Michael Gove said: Thereaposs no fixed point, no specic date in the calendar at which we can say things will change, we are keeping them under review. One key government doctor has said some measures may be in place for up to six months. Dr Jenny Harries, deputy chief medical officer, said of the rules last week: Three weeks for review, two or three months to seeweaposve really squashed it, but three to six months, ideally, but lots of uncertainty in that but then to see at which point we can actually get back to normal and it is plausible it could go further than that. This is not to say we would be in complete lockdown for six months, but as a nation we have to be really, really responsible and keep doing what weaposre all doing until weaposre sure we can gradually start lting ious interventions which are likely to be spaced - based on the science and our data - until we gradually come back to a normal way of living. What needs to happen before the lockdown can end  Ministers and scientists have been reluctant to say what requirements must be met before they relax the rules and are still emphasising the importance of social distancing. Business Secretary Alok Sharma has warned there could be another rise in casesthe measures are lted too quickly. He told a press conference on Wednesday: Whataposs also really important is thatwe stop these too quickly, there is a possibility that that massive effort people have made across the country is wasted and we could potentially see a dangerous second peak. We absolutely want to avoid that. One scientist has suggested that mobile phone data could help lt social distancing quicker by speeding up contact tracing. Prof Martin Hibberd, professor of emerging infectious disease at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said: A combination of some social distancing measures, extensive testing and automated contact tracing could allow both a more regular social activity and a signicant control of the outbreak.  Who gets to decide when it ends  The decision to end lockdown in the UK will be made by the Government alongside scientists and doctors. When the measures were put in place last month, the Prime Minister said they would be reviewed every three weeks. Top NHS doctor Professor Stephen Powis said scientists are still focusing on learning how the illness works. He said on Saturday: It is very likely that this virus will become established in populations throughout the world and so we need a strategy to manage this over time, not just in the next few weeks or the next few months. Scientic knowledge about this virus is still being discovered. As we learn more about it, as the scientic evidence builds, that will allow those strategies to evolve. Professor Graham Medley, who is advising the government, has told The Times the shutdown is merely buying time and there is no clear exit strategy from the Covid- crisis. He said: This disease is so nasty that we had to suppress it completely. Then weaposve kind of painted ourselves into a corner, because then the question will be, what do we do now  We will have done three weeks of this lockdown, so thereaposs a big decision coming up on April . In broad terms are we going to continue to harm children to protect vulnerable people, or not

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The lockdown has been tough for many and Prime Minister Boris Johnson has warned that things are likely to get a lot worse before they get better.As the death toll hit , yesterday Health Secretary Matt Hancock told the public that staying at home was an instruction and not a request. While officials cannot answer how long we could remain in lockdown, it seems this could go on for months. But while there are of course a raft of things that are getting worse and suffering we are seeing many positives of being placed on lockdown.After a decade of austerity and four years of a nation torn in half by the Brexit debate, Covid- has reignited a sense of community in Britain.We do not know when le will go back to normal but as neighbourliness, nature and air quality resurges, Britons might decide they do not entirely want it to.  Here are some of the changes the Covid- pandemic might bring:Travel The lockdown has left the travel industry in a parlous state with thousands of planes grounded, trains and coaches suspending routes and a rapid drop in use of bus and local train travel. It has also revealed the extent to which technology has made a lot of business travel obsolete. AA President Edmund King told the BBC: People travelling up and down motorways just to hold meetings is inefficient, expensive and not good for the environment, he said. I think use of roads and rail and indeed bus will be reduced after this crisis. Work Many people lucky enough to have desk-based jobs have reported the transition from office-based to home-based working to be relatively straight forward. With the proleration of conference apps like Zoom and Skype, video conferencing and remote working is a lot more reliable than it once was, and could potentially open up the workplace to people previously shut out. James Taylor, head of strategy, impact and social change at disability equality charity, Scope, said: Businesses that work flexibly thrive, so long may this continue after the pandemic has faded. The average Britonaposs commute is around  minutes a day -  minutes in London - and post-shut down many will be sad to relinquish the extra few minutes in bed or a little more family time to be in the office for am. More people are likely to ask to work from home one to two days per week, easing pressure on the transport system and reducing stress among the workforce. Air quality One of the benefits of the shutdown has been a rapid increase in air quality in cities as cars sit idle, and hundreds of people have remarked on how clear the birdsong is without the rumble of traffic. Mayor of London Sadiq Khan said in a recent interview that lack of progress on toxic air is the biggest frustration of his time in office, despite measures introduced to limit the most polluting vehicles.But the current change to the status quo might mean the Old Smoke and other UK cities are never quite the same again. A spokesman for the Mayoraposs Office said: Once the current emergency has passed, our challenge will be to do all we can to have cleaner air at all times which is why schemes like the Ultra Low Emission Zone and the further roll out of electric vehicle charge points will be vital. Demise of cash Cash is no longer king in this age of infection as people contemplate just how many hands their notes have passed through. Last month, the contactless limit was raised from £ to £ to allow shoppers to make larger purchases without having to punch their pin into a potentially dirty keypad.  While this is convenient for internet-enabled age groups and the salaried classes, it can spell dficulties for the elderly and those in the gig economy as banks shut their doors and ATMs are removed. Gareth Shaw, head of money for consumer advice group Which  warned that the move towards cashless, while well-intentioned, could hurt vulnerable groups - particularlyinitiatives like mobile bank branches are permanently withdrawn. Broadband Speedy internet has been a godsend for everyone stuck in doors.But internet black spots are still common in rural areas, with the situation so bad that Rishi Sunak pledged to pump £ billion into the rollout of full-fibre broadband in the latest budget in a bid to level up the UK.Councillor Mark Hawthorne, digital connectivity spokesman for the Local Government Association , said: We have long-called for funding and support to bridge the digital connectivity gap. He added: The LGA has previously called for a apossocial tarfapos to ensure a basic service is available at an affordable price to those most in need. Local shops Independent grocery shops have experienced an unexpected renaissance during the Covid- crisis in an otherwise bleak outlook for the high street.  While images of empty shelves and tales of month-long waiting lists for deliveries from major supermarket chains have taken over social media, most corner shops have kept calm and well stocked. Consumer intelligence company Springboard thinks it might mark a change in the way we shop. Diane Wehrle, insights director at Springboard, said: Now that they are once again familiar to consumers and being successful in delivering what is required, this episode may well provide a much needed catalyst for shopping locally and supporting small stores. Waste Now trips outside are strictly limited, many households are thinking of ways to make their shopping go that little bit further. There has been a proleration of articles on how to reduce waste and save cash in uncertain times, with Great British Bake Off star Nadia Hussain even teaching the frugal nation how to cook up banana skins. There is also the issue of what overflowing bins mean for our health as councils cut back on collection and recycling services.  Community After years of political arguments and ision, all of a sudden we are a nation dreaming up ways to help our communities. From clapping the NHS, hundreds of thousands of people signing up as crisis volunteers or just getting to know your neighbours, the past few weeks have been full of stories of solidarity. We could be in for a year of periods of greater and lesser social isolation as we wait for a vaccine to be developed and while it will be tough, this time of crisis is bringing us all together. Childcare Parents have found they are not only breadwinners, but also teachers and live-in entertainers for their children, placing a huge amount of stress on an already dficult situation. One head teacher at a primary school in Essex advises parents not to put too much pressure on themselves.  What this will show is just how much training teachers have to do their job, she said. At the end of the day, parents should only try and teach their children what they are comfortable teaching them, and should focus on just keeping them happy and busy and using their brains. Government intervention In the last few weeks the Government has pledged hundreds of billions of pounds to prevent the collapse of the economy - offering increased support to employees, self-employed and unemployed alike.

It would show his father had not been a labourer from Hull but an American G.I. who had a fling with his mum and went on to become a D-Day hero. When Graham got the results of his sample from ancestry site MyHeritage saying he had a sister in America he ­assumed there must be a mistake. But when he began chatting to his DNA match Kitty Sala, , the truth about his father started falling into place. Kitty’s dad Harry Atwell Pittmann had been posted to England before the ­D-Day landings in June .  He had been briefly stationed in Graham’s native Hull in the February of that year – exactly nine months before his late mum Elizabeth gave birth. There was another shock for Graham, who has ten siblings. His past had not been such a secret to them. They revealed they’d known for years he was the product of an affair but had not wanted to upset him. In November Graham and we Ros, , travelled to Seattle, Washington, where he had an emotional first meeting with Harry’s family. They greeted him with a sign which read: “Welcome Home Brother”. Graham said: “I was always made to feel part of the family.” The Americans’ reaction had been a great boost to Graham after the emotional upheaval of the test results. He admitted his family tree research had been getting nowhere so he had sent off for the kit. He said: “When I logged in, it showed Kitty was a very high positive result – likely a sister or an aunt. Her two children were also strong matches – they came out as likely to be my nephew and niece. I said to my we, ‘This can’t be right. It’s saying I’ve got relations in the States’.” The shock set in after Graham spent a few days corresponding with Kitty. He said: “It seemed like a bit of a bereavement – thinking you’d lost everything you knew. My feelings were all over the place. “But meeting my American family was overwhelming. MyHeritage had arranged cameras, it was quite a moment. “As I went down the escalator to meet them all, I thought, ‘Woah’. But It was a fantastic meeting.”  Graham, who spent  years in the Army himself, was filled with pride when he was told his dad was a D-Day veteran. Harry was one of thousands of US soldiers who landed on the beaches of Normandy on June  – and saw dozens of his comrades shot before his eyes. Codenamed Operation Overlord, the largest seaborne invasion in history helped turn the tide of the Second World War and allowed the allies to advance into western Europe. By the time Graham was born in the November of that year Harry, then aged , had pushed into Germany – with no inkling he had a son in England. The dad of five, who died of bowel cancer aged  in , never got over what he’d seen on the French beaches. Graham said: “My siblings say he ­remembered the horric situation many of our soldiers went through on D-Day – getting off the beach, having friends shot on landing, or while just getting off the landing craft. “Like many of the guys, he suffered with that memory for the rest of his le. I feel very proud of him. It was quite a poignant moment when we went to the military cemetery where he is buried. “There are lots of similarities between us as we both spent years in the military. He was in the American engineers and I was in the British engineers. I feel sad that I didn’t get to meet my dad. “When you find out things like this, there are all sorts of questions you want to ask. He didn’t know I ­existed – the family sayhe did know, he would have come back. Luckily, I can speak to my brothers and sisters.”  Harry ed to the US when the war ended in  and married shortly afterwards, before having Kitty and her siblings Marsha, , Harry, , Sharon, , and Michael, . All of his children have marvelled at how much Graham looks like their late dad. When Graham probed his own ­family about the secret, they confirmed their labourer dad Arthur spent three years in Myanmar, then known as Burma, during the war. Arthur was posted in the country fighting the Japanese at the time Graham was conceived – meaning he could not have been his ­biological dad. Graham said: “I knew he’d served in the war – I’ve got his medals – but I didn’t give the dates any thought. “He was scarred as well when he came home. I don’t want to forget that. I asked my siblings, ‘Didn’t you even think to tell me ’ They said: ‘What was the point  You were our brother and you were part of the family’.
